nodes.bodyText: Why are you changing the order? The habit of putting the constant first is deliberate.

Readability of code. Having the constant first protects against bad coding habits and typos, but significantly increases the difficulty of reading the code.
This way is the preferred styling for Java, as shown in most standard coding guides.

We generally avoid stylistic changes outside the immediate area being changed, if only to decrease the cognitive burden reviewing changes.
That said, as a long time C/C++ programmer, I probably introduced a lot of those.
It only affects the readability of the code if you haven't gotten used to it yet. Having the constant second is more typical, but it is not best practice.

Modern best practice is to make it readable, and code review to catch any issues with assignment versus a comparison.
Also, constant first is normally only used for ==, not != comparisons, as issues are more likely to occur there.
This adds blank lines between the table header and the first row.

nodes.bodyText: Okay, this is weird, I swear that was between two if statements with the VSTOL checks.... Will fix this now.

nodes.bodyText: isVSTOL is never defined in the template data model, causing the text version to fail. This also needs to exclude fixed wing support, which gain VSTOL capabilities through a chassis modification, which is listed elsewhere. That's probably best done by changing the definition of isConventional to exclude support vehicles.
Okay, now I'm sure there's something up, cause I know I put in isVSTOL (mostly because I forgot it originally and got an error during testing). I think my last commit might not have gone through...

As indicated by the comment above, if an exception is thrown while loading the unit, mechView will still not be initialized. The exception is already caught and logged, but removing this null check will cause another exception to be thrown which may cause the ui to stop responding.
If you look under that comment, it sets populateTextFields to false. That will also trigger this IF statement as false, so the mechview != null check is not required.
Sure enough

This duplicates code already present in TestAero. Where possible, calculations related to construction rules, when not required to load the unit or required during gameplay, should be placed the megamek.common.verifier package rather than the Entity. This will also report an incorrect value for FixedWingSupport, which adds VSTOL capability through a chassis modification.
Good to know, and fixed.
Strings that are displayed to the user should go in the i18n resource file.
How do you handle untranslated string for German or Russian? Should I do VSTOL_de, de_VSTOL, leave it out?
Don't worry about the translations. Just put it in the default locale so if or when someone volunteers to update the translations it will be there for them.
This is better, but I would suggest String#isEmpty
I agree, changed them all to isEmpty calls instead.
